- [Rafael] Hello, and welcome
to a new video series.
focusing on Amazon DevOps Guru,

a machine learning
powered service from AWS,
helping developers

and operators automatically
detect anomalies,
and improve application availability.
My name is Rafael Ramos.
I'm a senior solutions architect with AWS,

and I'll be leading you
through this first episode.

In this introduction, we'll
establish a foundation
about how AWS is bringing AI and ML

into the development,
and operation workflows,

to materialize what we

We also cover the basic
concept of DevOps Guru,
and typical use cases.
In subsequent episodes,

we'll dive deeper into
concepts, best practices,

Guru in specific contexts.

Regardless of whether
you are a small business,
or an enterprise,

applications are becoming more
distributed and more complex.
Because of this, maintaining and improving
application availability,

and resolving operational
issues is difficult.

Solutions, demand additional
dashboards, alarms,
and metrics, that allow you to monitor
all the IT resources and applications.

Every time you add a
new service or resource,

you need to complete the
observability coverage.
This entails manually enabling monitoring,

configuring all the alarms,
and setting various metrics.

You also need to define
different thresholds
for alarms, which is a very tricky task.
From an operational perspective,
configuring all that manually,
and collecting aggregated metrics

from so many different
resources can be overwhelming.
When an issue occurs,

there are multiple alarms
you must deal with.

Then you need to stitch together
all the various data points

and correlate the failures
with potential causes
for the issue.

This process usually takes a
significant amount of time.
And because of that,

your meantime to recovery
or MTTR, is affected.

Your customers are then
impacted with downtime,
or poor user experience.

Think about the number of
alarms, metrics, and traces,
that an operator must track,

in order to find the
root cause of an issue
on a microservices environment,
with dozens, or hundreds of applications.

Then, think about the number
of alarms and thresholds

you need to enable just
to have full coverage.

This is why Amazon
DevOps Guru was created.
With its ML based anomaly detectors,
DevOps Guru makes it easy
to improve application availability,

nd this is the key aspect
I want to highlight
in this introduction.
Our approach towards NextGen DevOps
is to apply machine learning

to operational data
from your AWS resources.
So when an anomalous behavior is detected,

instead of having noise from
several different alarms,
DevOps Guru provides an intelligent digest

of various events and
anomalies that you can use
to quickly find the root cause issue,
and reduce the MTTR.
DevOps Guru is a fully managed service,

which means you don't need
machine learning expertise.
It uses pretrained models,
informed by years of experience

from amazon.com, and AWS
operational excellence.

These models can identify
anomalous application behavior
such as increased latency, error rates,
and resource constraints,
and surface critical issues

that could cause potential
outages, or service disruptions.
You don't have to manually configure

tons of alarms and thresholds
across your AWS resources.
With these pre-trained ML models,

DevOps Guru implicitly sets
thresholds dynamically,
based on the behavior of the application,
and alerts you

only when the implicit
thresholds are breached.
For example,
if your application typically handles
10 requests per second,

and suddenly the number of
requests increases to 1000,
you might be under DDoS attack,
and DevOps Guru will notify you.

On the other hand, if these
1000 requests per second
become the standard traffic,

you don't have to change
the threshold manually,
because DevOps Guru anomaly detectors
will adapt accordingly.

Enabling DevOps Guru is as
simple as clicking a button,

and providing guidance about
your application boundaries.
To understand the applications' behavior,
DevOps grew automatically starts
to monitor the AWS resources,
by ingesting CloudWatch vendored metrics
and AWS CloudTrail events.
On its dashboard,

DevOps Guru doesn't display
fancy graphs, charts,
or running counters.
This is by design,
because we want to upload you
from monitoring the system's health.
DevOps Guru takes care of this aspect,

and only notifies you when
an anomalies detected.
When this happens,
DevOps Guru correlates issues, and trails,

to provide you with a
meaningful sequence of events,
which is called an insight.
Instead of dealing with multiple alarms
that don't pinpoint the symptoms,
and root cause of an issue,
a DevOps Guru Insight
groups together the information you need
about the failing resources,
and provides prescriptive guidance,

with recommendations to
resolve the issue quickly.
Now let's look

at how DevOps Guru
works behind the scenes.

This diagram depicts a simple
serverless application,
defined by CloudFormation template.

After it's deployed,
the CloudFormation stack

defines the application
boundaries for DevOps Guru.
This application has three main components
we can see in the diagram:
an API gateway endpoint,
that invokes a lambda function
to process the business logic,

in a DynamoDB table,
where we store the data.
Let's say that someone
accidentally updates the DynamoDB table
to reduce its read capacity.
At the same time,

there is a surge of HTTP
traffic to the application.

Eventually, the DynamoDB
table will be throttled,

because it can't keep
up with the new number
of read requests.
In this hypothetical scenario,

the operator would see all
three components failing.
The DynamoDB table would be throttled.

The lambda function would
have failed executions,
and the API gateway endpoint would respond
with 500 HTTP errors.
To resolve this issue,
the operator would need to understand
the root cause of the issue,
and what the side effects are.

In this case, even though
the lambda function,

and the API gateway
endpoint, are both failing.

they're just side
effects of the root cause

which is the reduced capacity
of the DynamoDB table.
After resolving the incident,

the operator would have to spend
more time on a post mortem,
to identify the read capacity
of the DynamoDB table being decreased,

because of a bug in a
previous application release.
This is how DevOps Guru can help you

with machine learning
based anomaly detectors.
It monitors your application,
by ingesting operational data
coming from CloudWatch and CloudTrail.

In this example, DevOps Guru
checks the relevant events
on CloudTrail, and compares them

with the operational
metrics from CloudWatch.

Based on this data, when
it detects the anomaly,

it creates an insight, which
presents the relevant metrics,
so the operator can quickly find
and fix the root cause of the incident.
Taking it a step further, the DevOps Guru

can identify that someone has
changed the DynamoDB table

read capacity, just before
the anomaly was detected,
and recommends rolling back this change.
One thing to keep in mind
that after DevOps Guru is enabled,
it takes at least 24 hours

to create a reliable behavior
baseline of the application.
Let's take a closer look

at how to enable DevOps
Guru on the console.
Navigate to the settings,

and you'll be able to enable
it with just a few clicks.

You can either choose to
analyze all AWS resources
in the current AWS account and region,
choose specific CloudFormation stacks,

or AWS tags, to define
your coverage boundary.

Let's select choose
layer, and click enable.
Now we can see the DevOps Guru dashboard.

As a summary, it displays the
number of resources analyzed

in the last hour, as well as
ongoing and impacted insights.

We haven't selected our
coverage boundary yet.
Let's do it now,

by selecting which CloudFormation
stack we want to monitor.
Click on analyze resources.

and then on the manage AWS
resources selection button

let's select the option to
analyze all AWS resources

in the specified CloudFormation
stacks in this region

and select which
CloudFormation stack we want.

Then click on the save
button, and confirm.

DevOps Guru is now
monitoring the resources
from that CloudFormation stack,

and will create an insight every
time it detects an anomaly.

You probably want to be
notified when an anomaly occurs.
If we go back to settings,

you'll see an option to
set SNS notifications.

Click on set up
notifications, add SNS topic,
and create a new SNS topic.
Give it a name, and click save.

Now every time DevOps
Guru creates an insight

it'll send a notification
to this SNS topic.

If DevOps Guru sounds like
something you want to try,
you can start with the free tier.
At the time of this recording

the free tier includes analysis
of 7,200 AWS resource hours,
for each resource group A and B,

Guru API calls per month,
for three months.
And one last thing.
DevOps Guru has a cost estimator tool.

stack will cost you,
